Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
Auction offerings continued to be maintained around 6.7 M/Kgs. There was fair general demand. Orthodox Large Leaf teas met with mixed demand, whilst liquoring Small Leaf teas continued to encounter a bearish market sentiment following plainer quality.
Ex-Estate offerings totalled 0.96 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 0.9 M/Kgs on offer the previous week. Overall quality showed no significant change with a larger weight of the offerings comprising of fair average quality teas.
Better Western BOP/BOPF's - A small selection of teas were firm and dearer following special inquiry, whilst the others were firm and lower by Rs. 20-40 per kg in most instances. At the lower end of the market, a few clean leaf coloury BOP's gained by up to Rs. 50 per kg, whilst the others continued to sell around last. Corresponding BOPF's - Clean leaf types sold around last, whilst the poorer sorts were irregular and tended easier. Nuwara Eliya BOP's - N/A. Corresponding BOPF's, where quality was maintained, sold around last. Uva/Uda Pussellawa BOP's - Select clean leaf teas were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Corresponding BOPF's - A few select clean leaf invoices appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per Overall kg following special inquiry, whilst the others sold around last week's levels.
High & Mid Grown CTC teas showed no significant change and often sold around last week's levels. Corresponding Low Grown varieties - BP1's gained by approximately Rs. 50 per kg, whilst the PF1's sold around last with slightly more activity at the lower end of the market.
Limited activity from shippers to the UK and the continent. Selective buying from shippers to South Africa, whilst shippers to Japan, China, the CIS and the Middle East lent fair support.
Low Growns comprised of 2.6 M/Kgs. Leafy, Semi-Leafy and Tippy categories met with fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, Select Best and Best BOP1's were firm, whilst the balance were irregular following quality. OP1's, in general, were firm. Well-made OP's together with the Below Best varieties sold around last levels, whilst the balance together with the shorter varieties declined. High-priced OPA's were firm, whilst the balance were lower. High-priced PEK/PEK1's declined, whilst the balance sold around last levels.
In the Tippy catalogue, Select Best FBOP's were easier, whilst the Best and Below Best sold around last levels. Teas at the bottom were lower following quality. Well-made FF1's were firm, whilst the cleaner Below Best and cleaner teas at the bottom were firm to dearer. Balance sold around last levels.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy teas met with good demand and were dearer, whilst the Best and Below Best too appreciated. However, teas at the bottom together with the leafier varieties were firm on last.
World Tea News

Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers

Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
Irregular
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Western's - A few select teas appreciated by Rs. 50 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and often easier. At the lower end of the market, a few select clean leaf coloury sorts were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others continued to sell around last week's levels. Nuwara Eliya's - N/A. Uva/Uda Pussellawa's - Select clean leaf teas were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady.
BOPF
A selection of Western's gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular following quality. At the lower end, clean leaf teas continued to sell around last week's levels, whilst the others were irregular and tended easier. Nuwara Eliya's, where quality was maintained, sold around last week's levels. Uva/Uda Pussellawa's - A few select clean leaf invoices appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others sold around last week's levels.
OP/OPA
Well-made varieties declined by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts were easier by Rs. 60 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Flavoury PEK's declined in demand and were mostly unsold, whilst the Orthodox Leafy PEK's were lower by Rs. 40 per kg. Best PEK1's were easier by Rs. 60 per kg, whilst the others declined by Rs. 60-80 per kg. Best Rotovane PEK's were barley steady following quality, whilst the others and poorer sorts declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Select Best flavoury FBOPs were mostly unsold. Better Orthodox FBOP's were easier by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the FBOPF1's were lower by Rs. 60-80 per kg. Below Best FBOP/FBOPF1's were easier by Rs. 40-60 per kg and more at times, whilst the teas at the lower end declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg.

Large Leaf teas continued to sell well, whilst the others were barely steady.
BOPF
Better teas were mostly firm, whilst the other secondary types were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg easier.
OP/OPA
Well-made OP/OPA's declined by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the others at the lower end were easier by Rs. 40-60 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Bold PEK's were lower by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were easier by Rs. 40 per kg. Best PEK1's declined by Rs. 50-70 per kg. Below Best and bottom end types declined by Rs. 60 per kg.
FBOP/FBOPF1
A few Select Best and Best FBOP's were lower by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the others were easier by Rs. 40 per kg and more at times. Better FF1's were lower by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the others in the Best and Below Best categories were easier by Rs. 40 per kg. Teas at the lower end declined by a similar margin.

Teas in the Best category were easier by Rs. 30-50 per kg and more following quality, whilst the Below Best varieties were lower by Rs. 20-30 per kg. Teas at the lower end of the market declined by Rs. 20 per kg. Low Growns - In general, were easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg. CTC - In general, were firm to dearer.
BROKENS
Reducer varieties in the Best category were easier by Rs. 30-50 per kg, whilst the balance declined by Rs. 20-30 per kg.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties maintained around last week's levels. Below Best varieties which commenced Rs. 10-30 per kg easier, declined further towards the latter part of the sale. Poorer sorts in general held firm, whilst select invoices were easier by Rs. 10-20 per kg and more.

CROP AND WEATHER
For the period 04 - 09 June 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions
The Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported dry weather throughout the week. According to the Department of Meteorology, rain is expected in both regions in the week ahead.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions
Bright weather and windy conditions were reported in both regions throughout the week. Heavy showers together with strong winds are expected in Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions in the week ahead according to the Department of  Meteorology.
Low Growns
Bright weather was reported throughout the week in the Low Grown Region. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead.
Crop Intake
All regions reported a significant decrease in the crop intake.

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 09TH AND 10TH JUNE 2025 (SALE NO. 23)
Selective demand for the 195,179 packages (13,229,406.00 kilos) on offer with 45.43% remaining unsold.
MARKETS
Egyptian Packers lent steady support while Pakistan Packers, Yemen and other Middle Eastern countries reduced activity. Kazakhstan and other CIS states were more forceful on quality types while Bazaar and Afghanistan showed less interest. There was maintained but selective absorption from UK while Russia were less active. Sudan and South Sudan were absent. Local Packers showed some interest while Somalia maintained support at the lower end of the market.
OFFERINGS
Leaf Grades                   -    101,540 packages (6,683,590.00 kilos) - 55.54% unsold.
Dust Grades                  -     72,740 packages (5,438,720.00 kilos) - 38.19% unsold.
Secondary Grades          -     20,899 packages (1,107,096.00 kilos) - 21.47% unsold.
LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)
BP1:
Best - Some teas gained by up to USC90 with select invoices substantially appreciating by USC116, USC118, and USC154; a few lines however, shed up to USC8.
Brighter - Irregular varying between dearer by up to USC17 to easier by up to USC6.
Mediums - KTDA mediums lost up to USC10 with plantation mediums discounted by up to USC31.
Lower Medium - Shed up to USC11.
Plainer - Eased by up to USC17.
PF1:
Best - Irregular and varied between steady to mostly easier by up to USC10 but a few lines were up to USC5 above last levels.
Brighter - Fully firm to USC5 dearer.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were firm to USC2 dearer to easier by up to USC12 while plantation mediums saw irregular interest gaining USC13 to easier by up to USC4.
Lower Medium - Irregular enquiry and varied between USC7 dearer to easier by up to USC13.
Plainer - Shed up to USC9 but select lines were up to USC5 above previous levels.

Lower Medium - Irregular varying between USC4 dearer to USC10 below last rates.
Plainer - Easier by up to USC8 but select lines gained up to USC4.

KOLKATA SALE  CTC MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to good demand. Liquoring Assams improved in quality selling readily.
Earlier sorts irregularly easier. Few plainer Dooars seen selling around last levels.
BUYING PATTERN:
Western India: Good Support
HUL : Operating
TCPL : Selective
Exporters : Fair Enquiry
Other Internal/Local : Operating
KOLKATA SALE  DUST MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to strong demand. Liquoring sorts appreciating in value.
Remaining sorts firm to dearer.
BUYING PATTERN:
HUL : Mainstay
Western India :  Good support on the better teas
Other Regional Packeteers :  Good enquiry
Courtesy -J Thomas & Company
JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 06TH JUNE 2025 (SALE NO.23)
CTC LEAF
The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 80.16%(1,342,970.45kgs) of the total offering of 1,675,280.27Kgs
Demand:- Reduced and erratic demand on all sorts of teas on offer.
Market:- Best & good teas fetched irregular and generally lower prices on account of closely following quality barring select few invoices which sold higher on competition. The better medium teas continue to witness easier market with fair withdrawals. Medium & plainer larger broken at the lower end sold barely steady whilst the remainders saw a decline in prices in the range of Rs 2 to 3 compared to last week. Browner sorts continue to witness withdrawals. The reduction in demand is mainly attributed to the decline in quality due to heavy rains.
Buying Pattern:- Western India and local packateers were choosy on the best & good teas in line with quality. Major blenders along with Western India Packateer were fairly active on the remainders but slightly reduced the absorption mainly on account of quality decline. Internal buyers continue to be subdued. Exporters were active on the larger and medium broken. The major blenders off take was 49.86% of the total CTC leaf sold.
ORTHODOX LEAF
Demand:- Fair
Market:- High grown whole leaf tended fully firm. Others declined in prices. Black, cleaner broken were fully firm whilst others eased. Fanning grades generally held on to last prices barring fibrous sorts declined in value.
Buying Pattern:- Exporters were the mainstay of the market. Internal buyers lent a fair support.
CTC DUST
DEMAND: - Sluggish.
MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 521,466.52Kgs of which 308,431.36kgs were sold (59.15%).
Best & good teas sold erratically as per the quality and competition. Select invoices at the top end of the better medium dust sold dearer on competition whilst generally was a lower trend by Rs 2 to 4. Medium and plainer teas saw a price decline of Rs 3 to 5 with larger percentage of teas remaining unsold.
BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were very selective. Regional and local packeteers were subdued, up country and the local buyers were selective and price sensitive. Exporters were fairly active on cleaner and blacker sorts.
ORTHODOX DUST
DEMAND: - Good demand.
MARKET: - Primary Dust selectively sold dearer otherwise was at barely steady to easier trend. Secondary teas declined substantially on the fibrous sorts others were barely steady.
BUYING PATTERN: - Regional & local packateers were fairly active on primary dusts. Exporters were selective on the secondary dusts.
Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd
